title: ALLIIGATOR TEARS

description.plain:
“​ALLIIGATOR TEARS” is the thirteenth track from ​Beyoncé’s album “COWBOY CARTER”.

The song uses the metaphor of ‘alligator tears’ to explore insincerity and manipulation in relationships. Beyoncé describes the emotional confusion of loving someone who displays insincere remorse, and questions the realness of their emotions.

This song may also speak to the abusive relationship the United States has with African Americans. Some parallels can be found in the lyrics:


“You say move a mountain/And I’ll throw on my boots/You say stop the river from runnin'/I’ll build a dam or two”. These lines may refer to forced labor.
“You say change religions/Now I spend Sundays with you”. These lines can show how enslaved Africans had their own religions and spiritual practices, but Christianity was imposed on them by the slave owners.
“Somethin' ‘bout those tears of yours/How does it feel to be adored?/You and your alligator tears”. These lines may allude to “white tears”. According to “The Root”, this phrase describes what happens when certain types of White people either complain about a nonexistent racial injustice or are upset by a non-White person’s success at the expense of a white person.



It encompasses (and makes fun of) the performative struggle to acknowledge the existence of white privilege and the reality that it won’t always go unnoticed. In “Formation” she also talks about “albino alligators” as her haters.

The way she sang the outro sounds very sarcastic/mocking. Almost as if she now enjoys causing her critics distress due to her success and resilience against them.

embed_content: Read “ALLIIGATOR TEARS” by Beyoncé on Genius

body.plain:
“​ALLIIGATOR TEARS” is the thirteenth track from ​Beyoncé’s album “COWBOY CARTER”.

The song uses the metaphor of ‘alligator tears’ to explore insincerity and manipulation in relationships. Beyoncé describes the emotional confusion of loving someone who displays insincere remorse, and questions the realness of their emotions.

This song may also speak to the abusive relationship the United States has with African Americans. Some parallels can be found in the lyrics:


“You say move a mountain/And I’ll throw on my boots/You say stop the river from runnin'/I’ll build a dam or two”. These lines may refer to forced labor.
“You say change religions/Now I spend Sundays with you”. These lines can show how enslaved Africans had their own religions and spiritual practices, but Christianity was imposed on them by the slave owners.
“Somethin' ‘bout those tears of yours/How does it feel to be adored?/You and your alligator tears”. These lines may allude to “white tears”. According to “The Root”, this phrase describes what happens when certain types of White people either complain about a nonexistent racial injustice or are upset by a non-White person’s success at the expense of a white person.



It encompasses (and makes fun of) the performative struggle to acknowledge the existence of white privilege and the reality that it won’t always go unnoticed. In “Formation” she also talks about “albino alligators” as her haters.

The way she sang the outro sounds very sarcastic/mocking. Almost as if she now enjoys causing her critics distress due to her success and resilience against them.

59 ContributorsTranslationsPolskiNederlandsBahasa IndonesiaPortuguêsBeyoncé - ALLIIGATOR TEARS (Русский перевод)ALLIIGATOR TEARS Lyrics
High tides in the city, I'm in too deep
And I'm runnin' on fear
Oh, dear, you and your alligator tears
Works me over and through

You say move a mountain
And I'll throw on my boots
You say stop the river from runnin'
I'll build a dam or two
You say change religions
Now, I spend Sundays with you
Somethin' 'bout those tears of yours
How does it feel to be adored?

You and your alligator tears
You and those alligator tears
You
Somethin' 'bout those tears of yours
How does it feel to be adored?

Sunrise in the morning, you're all I need
And all I need is rain or the roots get weak
Sweet things need time to grow
Thinkin' 'bout leaving? Hell no
Squeeze every ounce of love from my body, yеah

You say move a mountain
And I'll throw on my boots
You say stop the river from runnin'
I'll build a dam or two
